awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The impacts of massive Black Hole formation and evolution pathways on Gravitational Wave sources
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is part of a collaborative project to understand how massive black holes form and grow in galaxies in the early universe. The team will use computer simulations of the birth and growth of galaxies in the early universe with different black hole formation models. They will then look for differences in the predicted gravitational wave events between models. They will also search through the simulations for expected optical events that would be associated with the growth of black holes and possible gravitational wave events.

This collaborative project will look at three different black hole seeding mechanisms in cosmological simulations with galaxy formation models as in the IllustrisTNG simulations. These will be traced through hydrodynamical cosmological simulations to determine the astrophysical information that can be extracted from gravitational wave detection of merging massive black holes and electromagnetic observations of galaxies at high redshifts. The data from the simulations will be made public.

This project advances the goals of the NSF Windows on the Universe Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most galaxies that are the size of the Milky Way and larger have super massive black holes (SMBHs) at the center.  These objects are several million times the mass of the sun and significantly influence the evolution of their host galaxies.  It is uncertain how SMBHs form, but they remain an integral part of galaxies and so must be included in our galaxy formation models.

Because of the uncertainty in SMBH formation and because it is typically below the resolution level of galaxy formation simulations, many galaxy formation models "seed" black holes when a galaxy grows large enough.  In these models, black holes are inserted in galaxies based on empirical models.  We are now able to use these black holes to study their effects on the environment around them.

In particular, we are able to study how the behavior of these black holes influences the observable appearance of their host galaxies at early times.  With the lauch of the James Webb Space Telescope and the new detections of gravitational with LIGO and future gravitational wave observatories, we are able to make predictions for how and when SMBHs form.  We can then constrain these models based on new data from JWST and gravitational wave observatories.  It is also an integral part of being able to interpret gravitational wave observations.  This will lead to a revolutioanry understanding of early galaxy formation, black hole formation, and black hole evolution.
